H0.text: The temperature difference between the two groups was not great enough, so Andy’s experiment—which divided ten identical seedlings into a sunlit windowsill group and a cool dark closet group—could not properly assess the effect of heat on plant growth.

H1.text: The amount of light was different for the two groups, with one set of ten identical seedlings placed on a sunny windowsill and the other set placed in a dark closet on the cool north side of the house while Andy studied the effect of heat on plant growth.

H2.text: One group of seedlings got less water than the other, which is the error in Andy’s experiment that divided ten identical seedlings into a sun‑exposed windowsill group and a dark closet group on the cool north side of the house.

H3.text: Nothing is wrong with the experiment when Andy divides ten identical seedlings into groups, places one group on a sunny windowsill and the other group in a dark closet on the cool (north) side of the house to study the effect of heat on plant growth.

A4.text: Artifacts are factors that covary with the treatment and the outcome.

A5.text: Different wavelengths of light produce different changes in plants.
